newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shrs end higher to close year on quiet note.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shrs end higher to close year on quiet note.

text.p: Brazilian stocks closed up in weak trade as those investors not on holiday engaged in light buying and selling to round out a spectacular 1996 and prop up prices ahead of 1997, brokers said.
"It was a slow, peaceful day. Nothing happened," said broker Evandro dos Reis Junior of Indusval brokerage.
The Sao Paulo bourse's Bovespa index of 49 most-traded shares rose 0.47 percent to end at 70,399 points on turnover of 171.6 million reais ($165 million).

The lackluster session contrasted sharply with the end-of-year party that erupted at the close of trade on the Sao Paulo bourse as brokers and traders celebrated the end of 1996, a year that saw the bolsa surge 63 percent.
"1997 will also be a promising year," a broker said.
The bolsa is closed Tuesday and Wednesday for the New Year's holiday and will reopen on Thursday, when the upward trend is expected to continue in weak turnover.
Among blue chips, benchmark Telebras preferred rose 0.19 percent to close at 80 reais.
The session also saw rises in leaders Petrobras preferred, Eletrobras preferred B and Cemig preferred after the federal government sold minority holdings in these and other firms in Rio de Janeiro.
Petrobras preferred ended up 0.61 percent at 165.50 reais, Eletrobras B climbed 0.78 percent to end at 386 reais and Cemig jumped 2.91 percent to close at 35.40 reais.
The biggest loser among blue-chips was state mining giant Cia Vale do Rio Doce preferred, which dropped 0.99 percent to close at 20 reais.
The bolsa's Electrical Energy Index of nine most liquid power shares gained 1.81 percent to close at 1,940 points, led by Cemig and Eletrobras.
